algorithm_technique: Iterate up to sqrt(n) to find factors, storing them and counting. Handle the kth factor based on counts.
Iterate up to sqrt(n) to find factors, storing them in a list. Return the kth factor or its complement.
problem_summary_simple: Find the k-th smallest factor of a given number n.
problem_summary_technical: Find factors by iterating up to sqrt(n). Store factors and their complements, then determine the kth factor based on counts.
key_insights: Factors come in pairs (i, n/i). Iterating up to sqrt(n) finds all such pairs efficiently.
A special case is when n is a perfect square, where sqrt(n) is a factor paired with itself.
The logic needs to correctly count factors and handle the case where k is larger than the total number of factors.
Storing factors in a list allows for easy retrieval of the kth factor.
The second solution is more straightforward to implement by storing all factors first.
The time complexity is dominated by the loop up to sqrt(n).
